comments.commentBody: Gail's not unhappy, she's simply reporting on the demise of a once ok party to a quite unacceptable one.  Your reasoning is bit specious - Republicans are not tax collectors, they are tax spendthrifts and panderers to those who don't pay taxes at all.  Republicans are patsies - they are patsies for the citizen corporations and irresponsible super PACs.

I would imagine that it might be hard to transfer a reward schedule that maximizes the rate of bar-pressing for pellets to the real world. The closest analog would playing slot machines. People seem to play until their money runs out because the next pull of the lever might be the one.

In a workplace, receiving rewards at random intervals that have no direct relationship to work effort or performance would probably motivate people to seek alternative employment. Rats can't leave the cage and those pellets are the only food they get.

"...the Boston Herald says that neither he nor anyone has been able to offer certifiable proof that Warren's great, great great grandmother was a Cherokee."

Ah, but has anyone offered certifiable proof that Warren's claim to be part Cherokee influenced her hiring?

"Sure the Repubs are being opportunistic and simplistic in trying to make politicl hay with this. If the tables were turned, Warren and the Dems would do likewise."

No, I don't think the Dems would. More of that false equivalency that to many right-wingers seem to feel needs to be hauled out anytime their "side" does anything questionable.

Let's turn something for which there is to date absolutely no proof--that Warren used her belief that she has some Cherokee heritage to game the system--into a cause celebre. Throw the mud and see how much sticks. The right did it with Sandra Fluke--there are people who believe totally that she she was demanding free contraceptives so she could indulge in promiscuous sex. A few of those people have even posted here. And yet that is a flat-out lie, a fact that was easily determined by listening to her testimony online.

Meanwhile Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas does several extremely questionable things that the Democrats pretty much let slide. Were Thomas considered a liberal, the Republicans would have had a field day and by now he would have either resigned or been on the road to impeachment.

Well, the Brown campaign could have responded that they consider this a trivial issue not worthy of discussion--unless and until something more substantive is proven, it's case closed.  But they didn't, did they?
Of course not.
It is also unproven that she used her belief that she is 1/32nd Cherokee to "game" the system.
It took Ross about three hours to come up with the column you describe.  And I never thought anybody  could make David Brooks look good!
Very well put.  Thank you.

Anyone who studies religious texts would realize that human beings are described as being half way between "animal" and God. People are physical but they have a soul (so they are also spiritual).

As such, the point of insitutions like religious institutions is to support the growth of the spiritual and reduce the influence of the weaknesses of the physical. In other words, the religious experience is not just a personal struggle but ALSO a SOCIAL endeavor.

In the past, Americans saw that the government (as we are a democracy) represented to some degree that social endeavor. There is a reason that some of the language used in our historical texts like the Constitution has a religious component. The government was suppose to represent the hopes, dreams, ambitions and potential of the entire population and that often meant dealing with the duality of human nature (e.g. crime and punishment, opportunity and charity, freedom and responsibility).

Current political discussion of the role of government seems to ignore all of this history. The entire conservative dogma seems to speak about money, individual achievement, personal ambition and competition (instead of cooperation). I am reminded so often how the people who are being asked to absorb the losses of the recession are the people with the least to give and that the people who have the most are asking for more. This is unseemly and goes against every religious text I have ever read (and this includes EVERY major religion).

There is a fine line between pride and narcissism, anger and hate.

It does not take much to fall in.
The Republicans make use of the fact that the devil is a fallen angel. Two sides of the same coin.

You are absolutely correct, Charles. "There is no wrong time to do the right thing. But the calculation of delay can erode the virtue of acting on what your conscience is telling you." The time to do the right thing is always the right time.

It matters not one whit to me that our President based his decision upon his Christian beliefs. He could have arrived at the same decision using the principles of ethics, or his legal training. To me, the overriding reason is always an ethical one. Whatever road leads to the right decision is a valid one.

We can no more deny people the right to live their lives in equality - regardless of their differences. If a person is human, he is therefore equal to me in the eyes of the law. Nothing else matters.

We will need all the courage we can muster to get through this election. Those who will side with this President need to know that, whatever the outcome, we are fighting for what is right. And, as this column states, what our President did was indeed just what was needed.
I am so proud of my President.
I'm very pleased with President Obama making this statement, and like you, I like leadership from my leaders.

As far as delaying this until after the election, what benefit would that give Obama? From a vote standpoint, if he didn’t affirm gay marriage he might lose votes by some liberals who would sit out the election. There are a number of disappointed liberals who are tempted to not vote this time, and he didn’t need to increase them. Now he is increasing the commitment from progressives. Blacks would likely vote for him regardless of their views on gay marriage—to avoid a gop president.

What advantage would there be in not affirming gay marriage? No conservative will vote for him ever, and for independents, this would never be a decisive issue. So he’d gain nothing. Politically he might as well affirm gay marriage.

And of course, now he will go down in history. And be seen as affirming a moral principal that belongs in a modern democracy—we need that badly!

Lastly, this decision doesn’t alienate big money in any way I can figure. So what’s the risk?

Thank you, you know, Mr. Obama, you know, that was a very, you know, inspiring, you know, quote.

I'm just teasing. Welcome to the club!

Talking about the failure to resist Nazism early on, the philosopher Hannah Arendt said that courage is not having the "right stuff."  Rather, it is the willingness to speak and act at all. The President has acted, and now he has spoken.  Equal rights is a constitutional matter, not a matter for majoritarian voting decisions.    MLK taught us that.  Now, it's up to each one of us to once again advance the equal rights project.
"Free at last! Free at last! Thank God Almighty, we are free at last!"
Maybe this will get the youth vote interested again after being disappointed for 3 years.
Obama clearly would rather have avoided this issue for now. Perhaps he would have announced this in the fall, perhaps not. Still, he did it and that's what counts most.

Proud of my president, proud of my country, proud on this historic day to be an American.

Looking forward to the day when Obama's opinion becomes the law of the land.

My entire ("traditional") family supports the administration's position on marriage equality. For us, it's an important family value to value all families.
Beautifully stated.  Thank you.

Yet Bo Diddley (and more recently George Thorogood) asks "Who do you love?".

It gets you thinking....

Bravo President Obama
And Joe Biden quoted them when he said "who do you love?"

No ; keep religion out of this civil right; and you will have a
civil right for all to be legal partners.

Discard the religious words from the new law; and it will be accpetable and all can then chose legal partners.

Christ does not ask us, "Whom do you love?". He asks us, "Do you love?"

Marriage equality is not only the right thing to do. It's the right Christian thing to do.
